88 AGRICULTURAL STATISTICS HAIL INSURANCE REPORT The following statement, showing the working of the State Hail Iusurance Law for the year 1920, was prepared at the request of the Department of Agriculture, by J. E. Hart, Secretary of the Department of Trade and Commerce, and included herewith as an interesting and valu - able addition to this statistical report: An analysis of hail losses and premiums as shown by reports on file in the Hail Department, discloses some surprises in the distribution of the losses and the sentiment existing among the farmers as to hail insurance. In the first zone consisting of 41 eastern counties the counties show - ing the large losses were York, Boone, Antelope, Hamilton, Platte, Wayne and Fillmore in the order named Seventeen counties in this zone showed no losses. Of these 17 counties the banner counties to show premiums reported were Madison, Lancaster, Colfax, Jefferson and John - son in the order named. Total premiums reported in this zone were $169,809.41 and total losses $160,401.93. During the season of 1919, premiums in this zone were $202,584.44 and the losses $167,785.64. These figures would seem to indicate that present rates are adequate in average normal years. The expense of adjusting is less in this zone on account of traveling facilities. In zone two, consisting of 27 central counties the large losses oc - curred in Custer, Dawson, Harlan, Phelps, Kearney and Buffalo counties, in the order named. Only two counties in this zone reported premiums and no losses, Holt and Blaine. Total premiums reported in this zone were $188,893.16 and total losses $246,481.89. During 1919 season this zone reported premiums of $311,021 59 and losses of $218,072.45 indicating that the present rates have paid all losses for the biennium and left a balance of $35,360.41 for expense of adjustments. In the third zone consisting of 25 western counties, the large losses were in Cheyenne, Sheridan, Chase, Lincoln, Kimball, Keith, Perkins, Morirll and Banner counties. Counties showing little or no losses were Hooker, Cherry, Hayes and Garden. The total losses reported in this zone totaled $353,556.96 and premiums $257,234.94. Last season the losses were $307,313.42 and the premiums $267,627 64. These figures indicate a total loss over premiums for the biennium of $136,007.80 in addition to cost of adjusting losses and administration. Rates in this zone should be very materially increased, approximate - ly 50%. Total losses 1920 _ Total premiums __. __$760,441.78 .__ 615,937.51 Losses exceed premiums _. —$144,504.26 Total premiums 1919 —$782,714.47 Total losses 687,732 20 $ 94,982.27 For the biennium total losses will exceed total premiums $49,522.00.
